description:
Sponsor: Arctic Liquid Freezer III on Amazon - https://geni.us/NrMtDT
This review of the NVIDIA RTX 5080 graphics card tests the new GPU vs. the RTX 5090, AMD RX 7900 XTX, NVIDIA RTX 4080, 3080, 2080 Ti, and more. Our benchmarks and review of the RTX 5080 compare it to the best video cards out in 2025 (so far) to determine gaming performance via framerate, efficiency and power consumption, and thermal performance of the Founders Edition cooling solution. The RTX 5080 is part of NVIDIA's new Blackwell architecture and includes a number of aspects being tested in separate follow-ups, including dual blow-through cooling for the FE (being tested in ITX), MFG (Multi-Frame Generation) that we have an explainer coming for, and transient power consumption alongside GPU thermals. Today's review focuses on the RTX 5080 and whether it's worth it as compared to other NVIDIA and AMD cards. We'll also address NVIDIA's problematic marketing (again).

Watch the RTX 5090 review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VWSlOC_jiLQ
And find more of the RTX 5080 specs here: https://gamersnexus.net/gpus/nvidia-rtx-5090-575-watts-rtx-5080-5070-ti-5070-specs

The best way to support our work is through our store: https://store.gamersnexus.net/

Like our content? Please consider becoming our Patron to support us: http://www.patreon.com/gamersnexus

comments.text:
Kena 50s 3060, 3070 80s 1440p

F1 60s 3060, 3070 100 1440p

New world 1440p 3060 70s, 3070 100

Flight sim 1440p, 3060 40s, 3070 60s

Forza 3070 4k 100,3080 130 on average 

Hitman 3070 60s 4k, 3080 80s

4060 4K tsunama at 25 fps, 4070 40s no DLSS 

Elden Ring no DLSS 1440p, 4060 40 fps, 4070 70
 
 
  4080 Forza 4080 110 fps, 4080 140 4K

Avatar 4k 50fps 4080, 4090 70

Hogwarts 4080 4k 45s, 60 4090
 
As you guys can see, I compared models directly under a higher class, as that's the only way it makes a higher class worth it since the jump will be bigger, which is why it makes no sense to compare a 4090 to a 5090 or 5080 to 4080 only 1 gen apart. It only makes sense to compare the 4080 to the 5090, which will skip the 4080s; this way it shows a good jump. The same goes for coming from a card like mine, 4070, to the 5080 or 4060 to 5070.

See how you guys are all comparing the wrong models

comments.text:
Hey Steve

I've been following your coverage of the RTX 5090 and 5080, and I had a theory I wanted to get your take on. Given the recent reports of Nvidia's Blackwell AI chips experiencing overheating issues in data centers, do you think it's possible that Nvidia has preemptively downclocked or limited the performance of the RTX 5090/5080 to manage thermal concerns?

One thing that stood out to me was Nvidia’s decision to remove hotspot temperature reporting from the 5090. It seems like an odd omission—especially if there were no underlying thermal concerns. Could this be an attempt to avoid scrutiny on potential overheating issues in the consumer lineup?

Would love to hear your thoughts on whether there’s any merit to this theory. Appreciate the work you do!

Given the benchmarks and the fact the starting price of the 5080 is $999 and likely consistently going to be more expensive. The RTX 5080 may end up being kind of a tough sell when the RX 7900 XTX exists with performance that is within' 5-10 frames of it. Normally I'd bring up the disclaimer that a brand new AMD cards might be more prone to instabilities but the 7900 XTX is not new and has already had more than two years worth of fixes and updates. 

I just checked PCPartPicker and some of the RX 7900 XTXs are as low as $830 but some as high as $1300. The average is about $1080. If the prices lower for the 7900 XTX cards or if the 5080 ends up being more expensive. Yeah... It's going to be a lot easier recommending the AMD alternative this time around. If the prices for the 7900 XTX stay about the same and the 5080 don't get super hugely inflated or they both end up being kind of hugely inflated anyway. It would be much much more of a 50/50 recommendation at this point. 

This is super interesting given the age of the RX 7900 XTX!

comments.text: The marketing seems to be the focus of nearly every channel, and I'm sorry I don't get it. I saw the original footnote clip, and instantly noticed the change and was like okay so they're using upscaling. Then looked at the fine print, yep, MFG. Okay well that checks out. To me it's just more of the old "up to" marketing, meaning if you can in one test repeatedly show that performance, then it's a valid statement. Is it accurate of the overall performance? No, but neither are averages derived from benchmarks if we're being technical. "The 5090 is around 27% better" when it should be if you were truly interested in being accurate "Anywhere from 5% to 50%" or whatever the actual numbers were, and then the reminder that this is theoretical maximum performance and not likely to be what any end user will ever see.

Can we get tests that actually correlate to the horsepower that is indeed built into these cards? No render sheds, vfx pools, or AI modals have channels that test... It's a secret closet monster for some of us that like to play games, but also enjoy working at the literal bleeding edge of technological performance. Which no game will even come close to utilizing with these vga's! But I can get to full video memory load, and to thermal pop limit in a matter of femptoseconds!
So..... Let em stretch they legs homie! Let em run fur eels! Less of this gaming performance from a channel that doesn't have much relevance in gaming these days, but tons in performance testing for games, and more raw dick dawg, full tilt boogie type shit! comments.text:
I don't care about RT, I care about high native FPS. I play my games with rasterization, or minimally required RT at 1440P native (or 1800P downscaled to 1440P) 165FPS on a 7900XT. So far I have not needed any upscaling or frame gen in any game simply because this card has enough raw power to do exactly that. I might need FSR..  in 2026. I've overclocked it to perform like a 7900XTX.

There are only 2 reasons to use DLSS: Ray Tracing, which half the time looks worse than raster, OR because  you cheaped out on a GPU and bought a 1440P monitor with a 1080P GPU. DLSS Quality renders at 960P and upscales to 1440P, you're not even rendering at 1080P. 

Native gaming is king. Best image quality. Only Native + DLAA beats it, but no Nvidia users do this because none of them have cards with enough raw power for native gaming AND a more intensive AA solution lol

comments.text:
@jarnovilen5259  7900xtx is not underwhelming by any stretch. Yes AMD needs better software for the "forced" RT games, but their drivers continue to increase performance somehow where as Nvidia usually only fixes bugs. Upscaling i can't comment on cause i never use it. A 7900xtx will mostly not need it except for a poorly optimized game like Wukong.  And Nvidia can harp on that 4x frame gen all they want but it's not fooling me. They should have called it 4x artifact generation.
Outside of the hilariously overpriced 90 series Nvidia can not compete with AMD's raster performance. That's a proven fact. And that 90 series comes at 2-3x the cost. 
And stop with the RT talking point. It was shit when it first came out, has been for years, and will continue to be so. For a tiny bit of lighting/reflection fidelity you lose 35-50% performance. It's not worth it and never has been. That's like putting shiny rims on your new car and losing 3-4 cylinders from your V8 motor. Every time i hear someone counter with RT performance it is usually nothing but an Nvidia fan boy trying to justify paying over MSRP due to Nvidia and their forced shortages and scalping issues. 
Lastly...  "amount of the GDDR is quite mediocre on the 7900 XTX especially." huh? 24gb is "mediocre"? Please stop taking w/e drugs your on. Apparently it's causing some major issues in your brain.🙃

comments.text:
Well, folks. We've figured out the target demographic for modern AAA titles.

They are geared for people who aren't interested in playing the games but instead just need preformance heavy garbage to be able to benchmark new hardware with, without requiring too much thought beyond making sure the testing process is accurate.

I'm not sure why this is the direction AAA studios are going, as this is a very small market niche, but who am I to try to tell Mr. Bethesda and the Big Money, Small Time crew that it just doesn't work.

Sounds like the 50 series is gonna be similar to the 20 series, some improvements but heavily reliant on a new "feature" that may or may not actually be utilized.

Like I'd be happy if the "Super" versions where like the old PS1 and PS2 slim versions.  Same basic specs, some hardware fixes but in a smaller package.
It would take a lot, Case and Motherboard standards changing but the writing on the wall to me is the GPU will become a more stand alone component like the PSU, will plug into the back of the motherboard and have its own compartment in the case. comments.text:
The RTX 5080 barely achieving single digit "improvements" over its predecessor that's nearly 2.5 years old at this point is a f*cking joke. 

I'm starting to get really sick of nVidia and the way they've been doing things since going from GTX to RTX cards. Pascal/GTX 10 series was the last generation of desktop GPUs from nVidia that actually offered value and felt like a good purchase. With each generation since then, rasterization performance uplifts have gotten less and less appreciable, taking a back seat to AI and RT/Tensor core hardware acceleration. 

Instead of concentrating on gaming performance, they've concentrated on the workload processes that have fueled the scarcity and scalping issues that began with bitcoin mining circa 2018, and they've been leveraging those aspects of the cards, namely the Tensor cores, to fill in the gap in performance left with cheap "AI" tricks of fake frames. 

As if that weren't enough, nVidia is still insisting on being dreadfully stingy with the VRAM - 16 GB of VRAM in the RTX 5080 is unacceptable! I can't help but feel like they're limiting VRAM knowing that it's going to result in people needing to upgrade their cards sooner. An extra 8 GB of VRAM, bringing the RTX 5080 up to 24 GB, would likely give gamers a couple of additional years of life on their cards, and I think nVidia knows this. Otherwise, theres absolutely NO reason that the 2nd tier offering from nVidia in 2025 should only have 16 GB.

And we all already know what BS their pricing is. In case others don't remember, when the GTX 10 series launched, the GTX 1080 was the flagship card, and it sold for $599, being easy to find in stock at MSRP. The GTX 1070 was $380. The following year, nVidia released the GTX 1070 Ti for $450, and what many still consider to be the GOAT, the GTX 1080 Ti, sold for only $699. The GTX 1080 Ti also had 11 GB of VRAM, which only makes the RTX 5070's 12 GB of VRAM and the RTX 5080's 16 GB of VRAM that much more of a disrespectful slap across the brow from nVidia. 

I am so sick of this company. They are the largest company in the world today (though they may have lost that spot thanks to Deepseek R1), and consumer desktop (gaming) GPUs only make up what, 10% of their revenue? And yet they still insist on gouging their customer base that gave their company a start and supported it all of those years before AI came along and acted as their big break.

To continue to run up the cost on gamers while underdelivering on performance is a complete disgrace in light of how much money they're making on AI.

And of course we can always rely on AMD to be as mediocre as ever and bow out of putting forth any sort of effort RIGHT WHEN the opportunity to win some market share was right about to fall in their lap. 

I'm honestly starting to reach my wits' end with this hobby.

comments.text: @temporaltomato3021  I didn't want to mention it in my main point, but I view the 5090 in some respects similar to the m.2 gen5. They are obscenely overpriced compared to relative performance of the similar predecessor, but for those wanting to be early adopters, the option is there. M.2 gen5 is obviously a lower use case than the 4090/5090, which has obvious and immediate benefits. I just compare the two as "out of my price range, I don't value that performance but I know someone will and does, and it's good for the industry if this new tech gets broader adoption." Problem is that generational gains from AMD and Nvidia are slowing while pricing is holding firm at $600-1000, which is frankly a lot. I don't see the expected cost efficiency reductions making their way down.

comments.text:
I see Steve is disappointed in AMD for not having an RTX 5080 competitor.  Looking at the rumor data, we have N43, N45, N46, and N47 missing.  MLiD brought up recently that Lisa Su wants to reign in on Radeon mistakes.  Think about the RX 6500 XT and lower tier RX 6400, these were deep budget laptop GPUs (RTX 3050, "5" Class) that laptop manufacturers did not buy and put into laptops, and Lisa Su wants to prevent this controllable incident.  As such, I am assuming N45, N46, and N47 are "complete" laptop RDNA4 discrete GPUs, but they won't drop into production unless a laptop manufacturer makes the contract for them.  As for the missing N43, I don't see a reason why AMD would not develop an RDNA4 refresh of the N31 design.  It was an MCM design that worked, unlike N41 and N42, making it a good back-up option.  Why would AMD hold back?  AMD thought the RTX 5080 would be equivalent to the RTX 4090 D, and an RDNA4 Navi31 Refresh would not be sufficiently competitive against such a card.

End result, the reason I see for the 2 month delay for RX 9070 Series is AMD wants to make the decision to commit to the "No High End RX 9000 Series Cards".  It is necessary for AMD to retract the "No High End" statement before the RX 9070 XT is released in retail.  AMD gave itself 2 months to make a final decision.  Honestly, a 3GHz RDNA4 refresh of the RX 7900 XTX at like $1,000 would destroy this released RTX 5080 and would be the perfect opportunity to grab market share.  The problem is if AMD can deliver it.  If an RX 9080 Series is possible, it will be late 2025.

comments.text: ​​​​​ @Darkyahweh If you're a computer scientist, then im the king of england, mate. First, we know that GPUs dont fully saturate PCIE bandwidth, and second, even if they did, the SSD and GPU sharing bandwidth is a real world scenario that every user will encounter if they populate an M.2 ssd drive in that top, highest performing NVME slot. Also, how did you even arrive at your estimate of 1%-4% performance difference without an SSD sharing the top NVME slot? If those types of FPS results were being measured, it would be pretty well known. In a game with 200 fps, 4% is 8 fps difference, which also strikes me as being within margin of wrror between different testing systems. Overall, you sound crazy.
comments.author: @evanwheeler7687

comments.text: @Darkyahweh  Well, Mr. Computer Scientist, if you had bothered to read the User Manual for the motherboard used in testing, you would have found out that populating the M.2 slots has ZERO EFFECT on the number of lanes allocated to the 16 lane PCI-e slot. Each M.2 slot has four dedicated lanes to it. The ONLY time that the 16 lane slot gets lowered to eight lanes is if the other 16 lane PCI-e slot is occupied at the same time.

comments.text:
@siotsoni9854  You're probably not as sensitive to 1% lows or you're not playing fast paced or quite the large breadth of VR games we do. I own almost 100 VR titles.

The issue that even AMD has verified but has stayed silent on since is frame times, not average FPS. There was a thread a couple years ago on r/AMD where an AMD rep stated it was a known issue and they were working on a fix, but nothing has come of it since.

I suspect it's due to their inferior codec trying to shove two high rez streams at 120hz down a single pipeline and there's zero argument that Nvidia has a superior codec. Not to mention the Index is not very high rez so I'd assume the issue wouldn't be as pronounced for you.

Either way, it's widely regarded on r/VR if you care about VR you simply don't use AMD, and my personal experience has verified it when I watch the SteamVR window showing frame times.

Then you still have to account for RT where if it hangs with Nvidia it's barely matching it, but when it loses whoa can it become a bloodbath. That's not something I'm willing to put up with if I'm spending a thousand dollars on a GPU. For a $500 card maybe since RT isn't amazing at that level to begin with, but not at $1k when that's getting deep into the "no compromises" pricing. 

Although I will be watching the 9070xt very closely because I'm just so sick of NV's BS and the wife wants a new GPU so she can play Indiana Jones. They don't seem to care about VR but if RT gets better I just might buy one.

@ my 6800 xt out performs my 5080 on many levels solely based on vram in programs like unreal engine and other development software. It still runs every game on max just fine with a few minor adjustments if you do your research and is significantly cheaper if you catch a good deal.

These cards are not actually very powerful without their AI cores which generate a lot of latency so is useless for multiplayer games and development.  So you only have a niche market of gamers who can ignore all the artificating that the cards would have a minimal performance gain on. 

The entire series is a scam. The better the quality of graphics the more Vram and Processing power is needed from the video card to load textures and models. so Only CORE clock and Vram actually matter.  With overclocking most amd cards can easily surpass most Nvidia cards for these applications excluding the 4090 and 5090 as they have optimal vram and core strength.

During the Cyberpunk part of this video I just stared at the mirror-like reflections on the floor and thought..  "that's not realistic at all, that's not what real life looks like, and it's actually kinda ugly". It reminded me of the hype for Bloom in the late 2000s.

Raster is still king. It looks better. People like RT cause it's "shiny"  but rain doesn't turn black pavement into a perfect mirror. It doesn't look better, it looks different, and it cuts your FPS in half to look different. 

Raster is still king. 1440P 144Hz native raster, often downscaled from 1800P to 1440P for a crisper image. Couldn't be happier. Unlike Nvidia cards in the same price range I actually have the horsepower and VRAM baqndwidth to do this. FSR is something I'll use in 2026 or something, which I'll take as a a sign of me needing to upgrade my card.

comments.text: @JesterFlemming  it's not just an echo chamber, I've never said anything about them before since I never owned one. I just used a 7900xtx for 4 days before returning it. GeForce is quick and simple for drivers. GeForce fps overlay is one hotkey, amd takes a hotkey then click another tab then click overlay tab then toggle on or off everytime. Freesync was constantly tearing on a couple games in full-screen with borderless being better but not perfect. This was a fresh build no previous drivers. Replaced with nvidia and all the issues were gone. Dlss is also superior to fsr. It's not a bad card. Pure performance it's good. It's a little cheaper. But someone with 15 years of nvidia experience everything is just quick, easy, and simply works the way I expect it to. I also desperately missed nvidia control panel for those days. Power management, gsync, 3d settings are all where I am used to them being.

Last hope for this generation for me is the 5070 Ti. I hope they dont lock it down like they did on the 4070 Ti Super, i bet it could have some insane oc potential because its using the same gb203 die as the 5080 with a few thousand cores disabled. Coupled with the GDDR7 memory and its $750 pricetag, i have hope for it...

Of course, I have a 7900 GRE so i dont really have much incentive to upgrade as i can get pretty close to a 4070 Ti Super with an overclock in most of my games (within about 3-5% rasterized performance), but it would be nice to see nvidia have a 16GB GPU that doesn't perform like garbage at 1440p and 4K under the $800 mark. Im just hoping the 5070 Ti will be within around 7-5% of a 7900XTX or 4080 without any of the upscaling BS. Ive seen games like Indiana jones push my brother's 4070 to its near-absolute limit around 11640MB of VRAM usage on 1440p medium, especially using framegen, and it only has 12GB so i have zero hope for the 5070 non-Ti despite its $550 pricetag.

comments.text:
@vorkzen4767  There's 0 point in having more performance if the price doesn't follow adequately. Otherwise, what's to prevent us from always getting Titan/90 class cards? The price doesn't matter, right?

To put their point in perspective, the 4080 was sold at 4090/Titan prices (and that was even without scalpers), while the upper tiers were sold at the price of a whole high-tier computer. On top of it, while it did have good ray tracing performance and good results with frame generation, the raster performance was NOT that 40-45% jump you're trying to sell, on top of its limited VRAM. It had 80 class performance, but not from its own generation, but the previous one... with a 80 Ti/90-class pricing. 

The 3070 on the contrary had blown everybody's minds when it was first released: it destroyed the previous generation in almost all tasks, had stronger support for NVIDIA's newest technologies (which back then was still very much in its infancy), and was properly kitted out to hold for a few years down the line. And all of that for an affordable price, before scalpers ruined it all. It had 80 class performance from the previous generation, into a good 70-class pricing. 

THIS, is what people want from NVIDIA, and this is why people compare the 4080 to a 70-class card. Because not only this is what the 4080 is doing, but is also doing so at a much higher price point.

comments.text:
I paid 600$ for the 8800GTX (#1 flagship card 2007), $400 for my ATI 5870 (#3 card after gtx 580/570 2010), $350 for my GTX 970 (#3 card after 980/titan 2014),  $450 for my GTX 1070 (#3 card after 1080/titan 2015). I really like to buy the #3 card. Any gamer who buys 90/titan class cards are just rich or they wait to get them used 1-2 years later (totally what I want to do this time around). Most people are going to be looking at the #2/#3 cards and in their minds, those are the actual flagships, because they give 70-80% of the performance for half the price!

Adjusted for inflation from 2010 pricing to 2025 pricing:

Titan Class should cost $1500-1600 (90 series) - these cards were always double the cost of the real 'flagship' for gamers. 

Flagships should cost $900-1000 (80 series)

Mid tier flagship cards should cost $500-600 (70 series)

Low end flagships cards should cost $250-350

Garbo cards used for monitor expansion = $50-200

Essentially, Nvidia and AMD both jacked the costs of their products up during the 2000 series cards (crypto boom + chip shortages + scalpers) and never went back down (the gtx 10 series cards were the best value/performance ever  so I can understand why they balked the next gen). So younger people actually think the current prices are 'good' which is just sad...

EDIT: What I find funny is the exact opposite happened in the CPU space. CPUs have gotten so much better and for so much cheaper that I now try to buy the flagship CPUs instead of the #3-4 cpus.

comments.text:
@ Intel had to have national security congressional hearings to get their new fabs past regulators and special interest groups that delayed construction for over a decade.  They were both at their manufacturing capacity and at the limits of what they could manufacture with their old fabs back in 2016.  There were acts of congress taken with Intel being the primary beneficiary. 

2nm will be great for phones and tablets but I suspect it won't be great for GPU's as power consumption and heat management is going to be hard to control.  nVidias clever use of daughter boards might be the solution to helping manage the heat but only time will tell.  The first graphene transistors were made this year at Georgia Tech, and from what I've heard we are around 6 years away from it being viable for mass production if it all works out like they think it will.

The only performance increases we're going to see over the next several years is going to be by throwing more cores and more power at the problem which comes at the cost of efficiency.  You won't see techtubers talk about it because they know negative press generates clicks, they are in fact running a business that needs to turn a profit themselves.

comments.text:
@ The 80 series was the #1 best card of any generation and was always super exciting. You must be younger. I remember when the 8800gtx actually made gaming viable for the first time on modern graphics back in like 2007. Or the 1080 giving us the same performance as two older flagship cards in sli. They were SUPER exciting.

It wasn't until Nvidia did 2 things that made the 80 series  seem quite bad on release. They started calling 'titan' class cards, which were NOT for gamers, as the 90 series...which made the #1 gamer flagships double in price...and they started to release the TI versions of the 70 series card. They would give 90% of the performance for just 60% the price.

So essentially, the 80 series cards started looking real shitty starting at the 4000 series cards. The 3080 was still super exciting at launch because everyone at the time knew the 3090 was just a titan and for the price, the performance was a joke. It wasn't until the 4000 series released, with such a massively better 90 series card, that made the 80 series card feel subpar. That make sense? It's really only this generation and last generation that the 80 seems, meh.

comments.text: @basicuser54  Money supply? Do you mean inflation.? Yes, it increased but not enough to justify the price increase from the 3080 to the 4080. comments.text: @drunkhusband6257  No it isnt. You still have the same input lag of whatever your native frame rate is and that is literally the most important metric when talking about performance. For instance. If you take Cyberpunk for example, if you are running 30FPS natively but with MFG getting you to 120FPS, you are still looking at 33ms of input lag from your frame rate alone, when you add MFG overhead, your display response rate, and CPU induced input lag to the equation, you are talking well north of 50ms+. This will feel like shit on a mouse and keyboard, and even worse if there's lots of variance in your native frame rate. MFG is a neat gimmick, but you really only stand to benefit from games that do not require any sort of precision aiming. An example of a game that would benefit from MFG would be something like Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 but virtually any shooter is going to feel terrible with it on.  I have a 4090, and when playing darktide with MFG on, aiming feels laggy, with it off, even with lower framerates it feels much better. with MFG on it feels like how Vsync used to be with a sub 60 framerate without freesync or gsync.
